This one alone is not going to do much. Please note that the initial deployment is just a normal devstack deployment, so you probably want to add here most of the settings (from  networking-odl-config-job) that are used by the "base" devstack jobs (devstack_services, devstack_plugins, other variables, but also tempest_plugins and tempest_test_regex)

If you check the logs, you should see that this is just a normal grenade-multinode job right now.

There are 3 kind of jobs which are executed:

- smoke tests after the devstack phase to ensure that we are not starting from a broken base; they are controlled by the vars.grenade_localrc.BASE_RUN_SMOKE variable and are enabled by default
- smoke tests after grenade, controlled by vars.grenade_localrc.TARGET_RUN_SMOKE; those are *disabled* by default

- normal tempest execution at the end; as in devstack job you need to define the following variables:

tox_envlist: all
tempest_test_regex: your_test_regex

and if needed

tempest_plugins:
- neutron-tempest-plugin
- ...

src/erasurecode_postprocessing.c.message:
To avoid complexity to parse the environ value, this is better. However, once I looked up and thought how to configure this value, it may be confused by *operators* because they may set false value (e.g. 0, false, no, etc...)

In current implementation, any value including such negative values will affect to keep legacy crc writes that could not be intended.

I know handling the values will increase code and make the code less simplicity so it may be ok to keep current code with notification in the changelog in the latter version bump.

What do you think?
The hope is to keep this if not hidden, then de-emphasized.

I don't know that I really want to add a bunch of string comparisons here, and then there's the casing issue... and what should we do if someone exports something unexpected like

 LIBERASURECODE_WRITE_LEGACY_CRC=sí

or

 LIBERASURECODE_WRITE_LEGACY_CRC=nein

? libec just doesn't have the same config expectations as swift... or indeed *any* config expectations, really...

That said, I could see an argument for requiring a non-empty value to get the legacy behavior -- what do you guys think?

Hmm... i didn't mean we have to supports every native language expression. 

Possibly, I may be nice to have:

Case 1. negative (i.e. not use legacy crc) patterns:

- LIBERASURECODE_WRITE_LEGACY_CRC == 0 or (not defined)

Case 2. positive patterns(i.e. use legacy crc) patterns:

- LIBERASURECODE_WRITE_LEGACY_CRC >= 1

Case 3. warning (i.e. ignore the value even if it's defined) patterns:

- LIBERASURECODE_WRITE_LEGACY_CRC is neither a natural number greater than nor equal to 0

the case 3 performs as well as case 1 but the case 3 emits the warning log like as "WARNING: LIBERASURECODE_WRITE_LEGACY_CRC is set with unexpected value, ignoring."

I mainly focus on how to avoid misconfiguration (or how operator can notify the mistake). 

Plus, we should like to have well-documented definition of the variable somewhere.

How does this look like?

whitebox_tempest_plugin/api/compute/test.message: Your new test effectively tests NUMA live migration with CPU pinning, right? So this test can go away - it'll never run upstream anyways (not until OE or some other multi-NUMA provider comes online, at any rate).

There is some additional coverage here that is not really handled by the CVE reboot test, e.g. multi-instance migration and updating acceptable pCPU ranges with VMs currently active on the host. Outside of the general live-migration tasks I'm not sure how much of these two tests share in terms of procedure to make a common parent class. I do think from an organizational standpoint since it's not testing NUMA as you said, it should either move to its own class in this module or move over to test_live_migration.  With emulator thread pinning [1] following a similar design pattern for how I'm handling vcpu_pin_set/cpu_dedicated_set maybe some new design pattern should be implemented to handle all these use cases?

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/687643/
Fair point, except that our current multi-NUMA test doesn't actually test NUMA node memory pinning. It just uses 2 NUMA nodes to test CPU pinning, which can be achieved like James did in this patch.

Does it make sense to try to have a goal of three general tests? #1 Being the live migration plus reboot, #2 would take the general approach of this test (multi-instance with just dedicated cpu pinning and live migration) but would be moved to another class, #3 live-migration with a focus on NUMA node memory pinning which would go here instead? When I say 3 tests I also just mean high level areas to test, with vcpu_pin_set and cpu_dedicated_set I know there is potential for additional variants.

Yeah, that sounds about right. Ideally we'd somehow reuse the CPU pinning live migration for both the NUMA live migration test and the soft reboot CVE test, since the latter is basically the former with a soft reboot tacked on.

> There is some additional coverage here that is not really handled
 > by the CVE reboot test, e.g. multi-instance migration and updating
 > acceptable pCPU ranges with VMs currently active on the host.

True, but that's more of an implementation side effect, as opposed to explicit design choice.

 > Outside of the general live-migration tasks I'm not sure how much
 > of these two tests share in terms of procedure to make a common
 > parent class. I do think from an organizational standpoint since
 > it's not testing NUMA as you said, it should either move to its own
 > class in this module or move over to test_live_migration.  With
 > emulator thread pinning [1] following a similar design pattern for
 > how I'm handling vcpu_pin_set/cpu_dedicated_set maybe some new
 > design pattern should be implemented to handle all these use cases?

I'd be careful of over-designing stuff. Let's do this one test at a time, refactoring if necessary. For this patch I've brought this up because we end up have two tests for essentially the same thing.

But... maybe in the interest of keeping things moving, and not block on overthinking stuff, we can start by adding your new test, and figure out this one later.

We may have a bit of an issue here, in that libvirt will do a hard reboot if the soft reboot fails [1]. It's fully silent (to the user) except for a log message, but when if it happens it could mean a falsely passing test here.

I think the likelihood of that happening systematically is fairly low (and the difficulty of detecting it is quite high - we'd have to parse the logs), so we can go ahead with this, but I'd like at least a NOTE or TODO.

cinder/volume/drivers/ibm/storwize_svc/s.message: The properties in this section are being registered to the backend_default section. Are we getting the retain_aux_volume property from backend_default section in the code? If not, this property needs to be registered in the appropriate section.

This section 'storwize_svc_opts' is to register the properties which can be defined under both sections 'backend_defaults' and a StorwizeSVC volume backend section. So, defined this property 'retain_aux_volume' under the section 'storwize_svc_opts' since it is very specific to storwize SVC backend. 
Any property defined under the section 'backend_defaults' is common and applicable to all storwize volume backends which is not the completely generic way. With the current approach, this property is restricted to a volume backend defined a specific storwize svc pool name.
From which section are we getting the retain_aux_volume property?
From any storwize volume backend section. It should not come from other sections like DEFAULT.

Do we need to send the retain_aux_volume property value for this delete rc volume method as well?

It would be better if we can directly get the configuration value for retain_aux_volume in the delete_rc_volume method.

ok .. so will you be doing the changes for the same?

Or is it ok to leave this delete_rc_volume as is? - because if delete_rc_volume is called from here and user has set the retain_aux_volume property in the configuration, then that value will not be considered here.
Yes. Making the changes to delete_rc_volume prototype and to function calls in order to pass one extra argument.

This property is not accessible to delete_rc_volume since it is a storwizeHelpers function. We need to make more changes after driver initialization to access that property directly from delete_rc_volume.

not retain_aux_volume

releasenotes/notes/victoria-release-prel.message:
I think these should be first class citizens and be at the same level as the 2 fixes above instead of grouped all together.

In theory the driver name should be going before the bug as per https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/contributor/releasenotes.html#drivers (no need to change it, since we have more release notes that don't follow these).

I did it this way because the bug authors and/or reviewers didn't think these worthy of a release note, where there's an attempt to say something about the change that would be helpful to people reading the release notes.  These are simply the bug titles, slightly modified in some cases to pull the driver name to the front if it applied to a single driver.  So they are actually a different kind of entry than the first class citizens.
Well, I think most of the time we just forget (I know I do) to ask for release notes when reviewing.
Why have all these been grouped when L36 to L45 weren't?

These are just the commit message subject with no attempt to explain what the fix does (they are very specific to the powermax backend).  I pulled out the REST API fix as of interest to everyone; the powermax fix I guess could have been kept down here, except it was easy to say what it fixed, so I just wrote it up the way it would have been in a release note.

My initial thought was that we should revert the change removing the config option name support, but I verified that it really was deprecated back in Stein, so there has been sufficient warning, even if I don't think the original plan in the rename patch was to remove support in this release.  The mapping is kind of pointless if none of the vxflexos option names are supported, but it's not going to break anything.  I guess the moral of the story is that the PTL should not take a few days off the week before RC-1 is scheduled!

ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/event.py.message: q: I do not see this new class used anywhere yet (besides test code). Is that right?

Correct. ovsdbapp doesn't really *do* anything itself, so this will really only be used by neutron/external projects. Switched the test to using this just to make sure that nothing broke.

Neutron actually inherits from the ovsdbapp/event.py version, so this change wouldn't be able to break anything there anyway. But I have a change in Neutron that updates their event handling as well (with or without this change).

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message: Consider renaming this to 'instance_cell'. It's clearer and it will make the below wrapping unnecessary. Type hints would be awesome (though not essential) too
nit: not you, but can you add a newline above this?
If the specified instance vCPU is intended to be pinned, we pin it to the previously selected host CPU.
Can you add a comment stating why we're doing this check?
Perfect. Can you add this as a comment to the code?

'InstanceNUMACell.cpu_pinning' tracks the CPU pinning pair for guest CPU and host CPU. If the guest CPU is in the keys of 'cpu_pinning', fetch the host CPU from it and pin on it, otherwise, let the guest CPU be floating on the sharing CPU set of this instance NUMA cell.
type hints would great (though optional, of course)
If you're making changes to this patch, can you remove this indent since it won't render correctly

This can be empty. We don't seem to be doing per-NUMA checks. See [1].

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1898272

            states_to_check['charm.bluestore_compression'] = [
                ('charm.bluestore_compression',

Yes, that is exactly what the states_to_check does. It informs the end user of the charm of the situation through juju status.

unit_tests/charms_openstack/plugins/test.message: out of curiosity: do you have to do this so that states_to_check() could call super().states_to_check() ? I'm wondering if we could do it in a way in which the inheritance order doesn't matter?

The order does indeed matter, and the test had it in the wrong order prior to this change. Python searches left-to-right through the listed classes [0].

This exposed itself now as the class is overriding a method that exists in both of them.

0: https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/classes.html?highlight=inheritance#multiple-inheritance
